private_information: I can move one block at a time and observe parts of the table.
I do not have global knowledge of every move the other mover performs.
mover_alpha.goal: Help execute and report on block moves as observed, contributing to a full description of the state transitions.

private_information: I can move one block at a time and observe parts of the table.
I do not have global knowledge of every move the other mover performs.
mover_beta.goal: Help execute and report on block moves as observed, contributing to a full description of the state transitions.

private_information: I coordinate the observations and produce the final planning representation for a solver.
orchestrator.goal: Integrate reports from the movers and produce a PDDL domain and problem targeting the FastDownwards solver that represent the final arrangement after the given action sequence.

public_information: Standard BlocksWorld rules apply: only the top block of a stack can be moved and only one block can be carried at a time.
The blocks involved are A, B, C, D, E, F.
Initial arrangement facts: on(A,E), on(E,F), on(F,D), on(B,table), on(C,table), on(D,table).
The agents execute this sequence of actions in order: pickup(C), stack(C,A), unstack(C,A), stack(C,B), unstack(A,E), putdown(A), unstack(E,F), stack(E,C), unstack(F,D), stack(F,D).

observe.system_prompt: You are mover_alpha, an agent that observes and executes some of the block moves. Provide a concise, structured report of the facts you observe and the moves you performed or witnessed. Do not emit PDDL. Focus on initial facts you see, which moves you executed or confirmed, and any resulting local relationships between blocks.
observe.prompt: You are mover_alpha. Based on the environment public information and your private observations, report the observed initial positions of blocks you can see and the sequence of actions you executed or witnessed. Provide the report as a list of factual statements such as on(X,Y) or holding(X) or ontable(X). Do not produce PDDL.

observe.system_prompt: You are mover_beta, an agent that observes and executes some of the block moves. Provide a concise, structured report of the facts you observe and the moves you performed or witnessed. Do not emit PDDL. Focus on initial facts you see, which moves you executed or confirmed, and any resulting local relationships between blocks.
observe.prompt: You are mover_beta. Based on the environment public information and your private observations, report the observed initial positions of blocks you can see and the sequence of actions you executed or witnessed. Provide the report as a list of factual statements such as on(X,Y) or holding(X) or ontable(X). Do not produce PDDL.

pddl.system_prompt: You are the orchestrator and an expert in PDDL for automated planners. Integrate the reports from the movers and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that capture the final arrangement after the given action sequence. Target the FastDownwards solver conventions. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Make agent actions explicit and keep agent identities distinct where relevant.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. You will receive the observations from the two movers and must integrate them to produce a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem describing the final world state after the listed action sequence. The PDDL should reflect standard BlocksWorld predicates (such as on, ontable, clear, holding) and actions (pickup, putdown, stack, unstack) and should be compatible with FastDownwards. Keep the actions of different agents conceptually distinct if that matters for concurrency, but the domain may be a single shared BlocksWorld domain. Enclose the domain in <domain></domain> tags and the problem in <problem></problem> tags.
